an3.79:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.79:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an3.79:2.1.pli: “Tīṇimāni, bhante, gandhajātāni, yesaṃ anuvātaṃyeva gandho gacchati, no paṭivātaṃ.
an3.79:2.1.eng: “Sir, there are these three kinds of fragrance that spread only with the wind, not against it.

an3.79:2.3.eng: The fragrance of roots, heartwood, and flowers.

an3.79:2.4.pli: imāni kho, bhante, tīṇi gandhajātāni, yesaṃ anuvātaṃyeva gandho gacchati, no paṭivātaṃ.
an3.79:2.4.eng: These are the three kinds of fragrance that spread only with the wind, not against it.

an3.79:2.5.pli: Atthi nu kho, bhante, kiñci gandhajātaṃ yassa anuvātampi gandho gacchati, paṭivātampi gandho gacchati, anuvātapaṭivātampi gandho gacchatī”ti?
an3.79:2.5.eng: Is there a kind of fragrance that spreads with the wind, and against it, and both ways?”

an3.79:3.1.pli: “Atthānanda, kiñci gandhajātaṃ yassa anuvātampi gandho gacchati, paṭivātampi gandho gacchati, anuvātapaṭivātampi gandho gacchatī”ti.
an3.79:3.1.eng: “There is, Ānanda, such a kind of fragrance.”

an3.79:3.2.pli: “Katamañca pana, bhante, gandhajātaṃ yassa anuvātampi gandho gacchati, paṭivātampi gandho gacchati, anuvātapaṭivātampi gandho gacchatī”ti?
an3.79:3.2.eng: “So what, sir, is that kind of fragrance?”

an3.79:4.1.pli: “Idhānanda, yasmiṃ gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti,
an3.79:4.1.eng: “It’s when, Ānanda, in some village or town, a woman or man has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.

an3.79:4.2.pli: pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti, sīlavā hoti kalyāṇadhammo,
an3.79:4.2.eng: They don’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants. They’re ethical, of good character.

an3.79:4.3.pli: vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato.
an3.79:4.3.eng: They live at home with a heart rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an3.79:5.1.eng: Ascetics and brahmins everywhere praise them for these good qualities;

an3.79:5.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti,

an3.79:5.3.pli: pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti, sīlavā hoti kalyāṇadhammo,

an3.79:5.4.pli: vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato’ti.

an3.79:6.2.pli: ‘amukasmiṃ nāma gāme vā nigame vā itthī vā puriso vā buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti, saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gato hoti,

an3.79:6.3.pli: pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti …pe… surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭivirato hoti, sīlavā hoti kalyāṇadhammo,

an3.79:6.4.pli: vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgo payatapāṇi vossaggarato yācayogo dānasaṃvibhāgarato’ti.

an3.79:6.5.pli: Idaṃ kho taṃ, ānanda, gandhajātaṃ yassa anuvātampi gandho gacchati, paṭivātampi gandho gacchati, anuvātapaṭivātampi gandho gacchatīti.
an3.79:6.5.eng: This is the kind of fragrance that spreads with the wind, and against it, and both.

an3.79:7.1.eng: The fragrance of flowers <j>doesn’t spread against the wind,

an3.79:7.2.eng: nor sandalwood, pinwheel flowers, or jasmine;

an3.79:7.3.eng: but the fragrance of the good <j>spreads against the wind;

an3.79:7.4.eng: a true person’s virtue spreads in every direction.”

an3.8:1.1.eng: “A fool is known by three things.

an3.8:1.3.pli: Sabyābajjhena kāyakammena, sabyābajjhena vacīkammena, sabyābajjhena manokammena …pe… abyābajjhena kāyakammena, abyābajjhena vacīkammena, abyābajjhena manokammena.
an3.8:1.3.eng: Hurtful deeds by way of body, speech, and mind. … An astute person is known by kind deeds by way of body, speech, and mind.

an3.8:1.4.pli: Imehi, kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito veditabbo.
an3.8:1.4.eng: These are the three things by which an astute person is known.

an3.8:2.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an3.8:2.2.pli: ‘yehi tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bālo veditabbo te tayo dhamme abhinivajjetvā, yehi tīhi dhammehi samannāgato paṇḍito veditabbo te tayo dhamme samādāya vattissāmā’ti.
an3.8:2.2.eng: ‘We will shun the three qualities by which a fool is known, and we will undertake and follow the three qualities by which an astute person is known.’

an3.80:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.80:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an3.80:1.2.pli: “sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:
an3.80:1.2.eng: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

an3.80:1.3.pli: ‘bhagavato, ānanda, sikhissa abhibhū nāma sāvako brahmaloke ṭhito sahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpesī’ti.
an3.80:1.3.eng: ‘Ānanda, the Buddha Sikhī had a disciple called Abhibhū. Standing in the realm of divinity, he could make his voice heard throughout the thousandfold galaxy.’

an3.80:1.4.pli: Bhagavā pana, bhante, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kīvatakaṃ pahoti sarena viññāpetun”ti?
an3.80:1.4.eng: I wonder how far a Blessed One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha can make their voice heard?”

an3.80:1.5.eng: “He was a disciple, Ānanda. Realized Ones are immeasurable.”

an3.80:2.1.pli: Dutiyampi kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

an3.80:2.2.pli: “sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:

an3.80:2.3.pli: ‘bhagavato, ānanda, sikhissa abhibhū nāma sāvako brahmaloke ṭhito sahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpesī’ti.

an3.80:2.4.pli: Bhagavā pana, bhante, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kīvatakaṃ pahoti sarena viññāpetun”ti?

an3.80:3.1.pli: Tatiyampi kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.80:3.1.eng: For a third time, Ānanda said to the Buddha:

an3.80:3.2.pli: “sammukhā metaṃ, bhante, bhagavato sutaṃ sammukhā paṭiggahitaṃ:

an3.80:3.3.pli: ‘bhagavato, ānanda, sikhissa abhibhū nāma sāvako brahmaloke ṭhito sahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpesī’ti.

an3.80:3.4.pli: Bhagavā pana, bhante, arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kīvatakaṃ pahoti sarena viññāpetun”ti?
an3.80:3.4.eng: “… I wonder how far a Blessed One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha can make their voice heard?”

an3.80:3.5.eng: “Ānanda, have you heard of a thousandfold lesser world system, a galaxy?”

an3.80:3.6.eng: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!

an3.80:3.7.pli: yaṃ bhagavā bhāseyya. Bhagavato sutvā bhikkhū dhāressantī”ti.
an3.80:3.7.eng: Let the Buddha speak. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”

an3.80:3.8.eng: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

an3.80:3.9.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho āyasmā ānando bhagavato paccassosi.

an3.80:4.1.pli: “Yāvatā, ānanda, candimasūriyā pariharanti, disā bhanti virocanā, tāva sahassadhā loko.
an3.80:4.1.eng: “Ānanda, a galaxy extends a thousand times as far as the moon and sun revolve and the shining ones light up the quarters.

an3.80:4.2.pli: Tasmiṃ sahassadhā loke sahassaṃ candānaṃ, sahassaṃ sūriyānaṃ, sahassaṃ sinerupabbatarājānaṃ, sahassaṃ jambudīpānaṃ, sahassaṃ aparagoyānānaṃ, sahassaṃ uttarakurūnaṃ, sahassaṃ pubbavidehānaṃ, cattāri mahāsamuddasahassāni, cattāri mahārājasahassāni, sahassaṃ cātumahārājikānaṃ, sahassaṃ tāvatiṃsānaṃ, sahassaṃ yāmānaṃ, sahassaṃ tusitānaṃ, sahassaṃ nimmānaratīnaṃ, sahassaṃ paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ, sahassaṃ brahmalokānaṃ—
an3.80:4.2.eng: In that galaxy there are a thousand moons, a thousand suns, a thousand Sinerus king of mountains, a thousand Black Plum Tree Lands, a thousand lands west of Godāvarī, a thousand lands north of Kuru, a thousand lands east of Videha, four thousand oceans, four thousand great kings, a thousand realms of the gods of the four great kings, a thousand realms of the gods of the thirty-three, of the gods of Yama, of the joyful gods, of the gods who love to create, of the gods who control what is created by others, and a thousand realms of divinity.

an3.80:4.3.eng: This is called a thousandfold lesser world system, a ‘galaxy’.

an3.80:5.1.pli: Yāvatānanda, sahassī cūḷanikā lokadhātu tāva sahassadhā loko.
an3.80:5.1.eng: A world system that extends for a thousand galaxies

an3.80:5.2.eng: is called a millionfold middling world system, a ‘galactic cluster’.

an3.80:6.1.pli: Yāvatānanda, dvisahassī majjhimikā lokadhātu tāva sahassadhā loko.
an3.80:6.1.eng: A world system that extends for a thousand galactic clusters

an3.80:6.2.eng: is called a billionfold great world system, a ‘galactic supercluster’.

an3.80:7.1.pli: Ākaṅkhamāno, ānanda, tathāgato tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpeyya, yāvatā pana ākaṅkheyyā”ti.
an3.80:7.1.eng: If he wished, Ānanda, a Realized One could make his voice heard throughout a galactic supercluster, or as far as he wants.”

an3.80:8.1.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana, bhante, bhagavā tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpeyya, yāvatā pana ākaṅkheyyā”ti?
an3.80:8.1.eng: “But how would the Buddha make his voice heard so far?”

an3.80:8.2.eng: “First, Ānanda, a Realized One would fill the galactic supercluster with light.

an3.80:8.3.pli: Yadā te sattā taṃ ālokaṃ sañjāneyyuṃ, atha tathāgato ghosaṃ kareyya saddamanussāveyya.
an3.80:8.3.eng: When sentient beings saw the light, the Realized One would project his call so that they’d hear the sound.

an3.80:8.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, tathāgato tisahassimahāsahassilokadhātuṃ sarena viññāpeyya, yāvatā pana ākaṅkheyyā”ti.
an3.80:8.4.eng: That’s how a Realized One could make his voice heard throughout a galactic supercluster, or as far as he wants.”

an3.80:9.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
an3.80:9.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said,

an3.80:9.3.eng: to have a teacher with such power and might!”

an3.80:9.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā udāyī āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ etadavoca:
an3.80:9.4.eng: When he said this, Venerable Udāyī said to Venerable Ānanda,

an3.80:9.5.pli: “kiṃ tuyhettha, āvuso ānanda, yadi te satthā evaṃmahiddhiko evaṃmahānubhāvo”ti?
an3.80:9.5.eng: “What is it to you, Reverend Ānanda, if your teacher has such power and might?”

an3.80:9.6.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhagavā āyasmantaṃ udāyiṃ etadavoca:
an3.80:9.6.eng: When he said this, the Buddha said to Venerable Udāyī,

an3.80:9.8.pli: Sace, udāyi, ānando avītarāgo kālaṃ kareyya, tena cittappasādena sattakkhattuṃ devesu devarajjaṃ kāreyya, sattakkhattuṃ imasmiṃyeva jambudīpe mahārajjaṃ kāreyya.
an3.80:9.8.eng: If Ānanda were to die while still not free of greed, he would rule as king of the gods for seven lifetimes, or as king of the Black Plum Tree Land for seven lifetimes, because of the confidence of his heart.

an3.80:9.9.pli: Api ca, udāyi, ānando diṭṭheva dhamme parinibbāyissatī”ti.
an3.80:9.9.eng: However, Ānanda will be fully extinguished in this very life.”

an3.81:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are three duties of an ascetic.

an3.81:1.3.eng: Undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.81:1.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi samaṇassa samaṇiyāni samaṇakaraṇīyāni.
an3.81:1.4.eng: These are the three duties of an ascetic.

an3.81:2.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an3.81:2.2.pli: ‘tibbo no chando bhavissati adhisīlasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo no chando bhavissati adhicittasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo no chando bhavissati adhipaññāsikkhāsamādāne’ti.
an3.81:2.2.eng: ‘We will have keen enthusiasm for undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.’

an3.82:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gadrabho gogaṇaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho hoti:
an3.82:1.1.eng: “Suppose, mendicants, a donkey followed behind a herd of cattle, thinking:

an3.82:1.2.eng: ‘I can moo too! I can moo too!’

an3.82:1.3.pli: Tassa na tādiso vaṇṇo hoti seyyathāpi gunnaṃ, na tādiso saro hoti seyyathāpi gunnaṃ, na tādisaṃ padaṃ hoti seyyathāpi gunnaṃ.
an3.82:1.3.eng: But it doesn’t look like a cow, or sound like a cow, or leave a footprint like a cow.

an3.82:1.4.pli: So gogaṇaṃyeva piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho hoti:
an3.82:1.4.eng: Still it follows behind a herd of cattle, thinking:

an3.82:1.5.eng: ‘I can moo too! I can moo too!’

an3.82:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco bhikkhu bhikkhusaṅghaṃ piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho hoti:
an3.82:2.1.eng: In the same way, some mendicant follows behind the mendicant Saṅgha, thinking:

an3.82:2.2.eng: ‘I’m a monk too! I’m a monk too!’

an3.82:2.3.pli: Tassa na tādiso chando hoti adhisīlasikkhāsamādāne seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, na tādiso chando hoti adhicittasikkhāsamādāne seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, na tādiso chando hoti adhipaññāsikkhāsamādāne seyyathāpi aññesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ.
an3.82:2.3.eng: But they don’t have the same enthusiasm for undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom as the other mendicants.

an3.82:2.4.pli: So bhikkhusaṅghaṃyeva piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandho hoti:
an3.82:2.4.eng: Still they follow behind the mendicant Saṇgha, thinking:

an3.82:2.5.eng: ‘I’m a monk too! I’m a monk too!’

an3.82:3.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an3.82:3.2.pli: ‘tibbo no chando bhavissati adhisīlasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo no chando bhavissati adhicittasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo no chando bhavissati adhipaññāsikkhāsamādāne’ti.
an3.82:3.2.eng: ‘We will have keen enthusiasm for undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.’

an3.83:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a farmer has three primary duties.

an3.83:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, kassako gahapati paṭikacceva khettaṃ sukaṭṭhaṃ karoti sumatikataṃ.
an3.83:1.3.eng: A farmer first of all makes sure the field is well ploughed and tilled.

an3.83:1.4.pli: Paṭikacceva khettaṃ sukaṭṭhaṃ karitvā sumatikataṃ kālena bījāni patiṭṭhāpeti.
an3.83:1.4.eng: Next they plant seeds in season.

an3.83:1.5.pli: Kālena bījāni patiṭṭhāpetvā samayena udakaṃ abhinetipi apanetipi.
an3.83:1.5.eng: When the time is right, they irrigate the field and then drain it.

an3.83:1.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi kassakassa gahapatissa pubbe karaṇīyāni.
an3.83:1.6.eng: These are the three primary duties of a farmer.

an3.83:2.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tīṇimāni bhikkhussa pubbe karaṇīyāni.
an3.83:2.1.eng: In the same way, a mendicant has three primary duties.

an3.83:2.3.eng: Undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.83:2.4.pli: imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi bhikkhussa pubbe karaṇīyāni.
an3.83:2.4.eng: These are the three primary duties of a mendicant.

an3.83:3.1.eng: So you should train like this:

an3.83:3.2.pli: ‘tibbo no chando bhavissati adhisīlasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo no chando bhavissati adhicittasikkhāsamādāne, tibbo no chando bhavissati adhipaññāsikkhāsamādāne’ti.
an3.83:3.2.eng: ‘We will have keen enthusiasm for undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.’

an3.84:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
an3.84:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

an3.84:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro vajjiputtako bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so vajjiputtako bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.84:1.2.eng: Then a certain Vajji monk went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an3.84:1.3.eng: “Sir, each fortnight over a hundred and fifty training rules are recited.

an3.84:1.4.eng: I’m not able to train in them.”

an3.84:1.5.pli: “Sakkhissasi pana tvaṃ, bhikkhu, tīsu sikkhāsu sikkhituṃ—
an3.84:1.5.eng: “But monk, are you able to train in three trainings:

an3.84:1.6.eng: the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?”

an3.84:1.9.eng: “So, monk, you should train in these three trainings:

an3.84:1.10.eng: the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.84:2.1.pli: Yato kho tvaṃ, bhikkhu, adhisīlampi sikkhissasi, adhicittampi sikkhissasi, adhipaññampi sikkhissasi, tassa tuyhaṃ bhikkhu adhisīlampi sikkhato adhicittampi sikkhato adhipaññampi sikkhato rāgo pahīyissati, doso pahīyissati, moho pahīyissati.
an3.84:2.1.eng: As you train in these, you will give up greed, hate, and delusion.

an3.84:2.2.pli: So tvaṃ rāgassa pahānā dosassa pahānā mohassa pahānā yaṃ akusalaṃ na taṃ karissasi, yaṃ pāpaṃ na taṃ sevissasī”ti.
an3.84:2.2.eng: Then you won’t do anything unskillful, or practice anything bad.”

an3.84:3.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu aparena samayena adhisīlampi sikkhi, adhicittampi sikkhi, adhipaññampi sikkhi.
an3.84:3.1.eng: After some time that monk trained in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.84:3.2.pli: Tassa adhisīlampi sikkhato adhicittampi sikkhato adhipaññampi sikkhato rāgo pahīyi, doso pahīyi, moho pahīyi.
an3.84:3.2.eng: He gave up greed, hate, and delusion.

an3.84:3.3.pli: So rāgassa pahānā dosassa pahānā mohassa pahānā yaṃ akusalaṃ taṃ nākāsi, yaṃ pāpaṃ taṃ na sevīti.
an3.84:3.3.eng: Then he didn’t do anything unskillful, or practice anything bad.

an3.85:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.85:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:

an3.85:2.1.eng: “Sir, they speak of the one called ‘a trainee’.

an3.85:2.2.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, sekho hotī”ti?

an3.85:2.3.eng: “They train, mendicant, that’s why they’re called ‘a trainee’.

an3.85:2.5.pli: Adhisīlampi sikkhati, adhicittampi sikkhati, adhipaññampi sikkhati.
an3.85:2.5.eng: They train in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.85:2.6.pli: Sikkhatīti kho, bhikkhu, tasmā sekhoti vuccatīti.
an3.85:2.6.eng: They train, that’s why they’re called ‘a trainee’.

an3.85:3.4.eng: enlightenment follows in the same lifetime.

an3.85:4.2.eng: such a one, freed through enlightenment,

an3.85:4.3.eng: with the end of the fetters of continued existence:

an3.86:1.1.pli: “Sādhikamidaṃ, bhikkhave, diyaḍḍhasikkhāpadasataṃ anvaddhamāsaṃ uddesaṃ āgacchati, yattha attakāmā kulaputtā sikkhanti.
an3.86:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, each fortnight over a hundred and fifty training rules come up for recitation, in which gentlemen who desire self-knowledge train.

an3.86:1.2.pli: Tisso imā, bhikkhave, sikkhā yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchati.
an3.86:1.2.eng: These are all included in the three trainings.

an3.86:1.4.eng: The training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.86:1.5.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso sikkhā, yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchati.
an3.86:1.5.eng: These are the three trainings that include them all.

an3.86:2.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ mattaso kārī paññāya mattaso kārī.
an3.86:2.1.eng: Take the case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics, but has limited immersion and wisdom.

an3.86:2.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.86:2.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.86:2.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.86:2.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.86:2.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni, tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.86:2.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.86:2.6.pli: So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
an3.86:2.6.eng: With the ending of three fetters they’re a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

an3.86:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ mattaso kārī paññāya mattaso kārī.
an3.86:3.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics, but has limited immersion and wisdom.

an3.86:3.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.86:3.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.86:3.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.86:3.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.86:3.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.86:3.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.86:3.6.pli: So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.86:3.6.eng: With the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, they’re a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

an3.86:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī paññāya mattaso kārī.
an3.86:4.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics and immersion, but has limited wisdom.

an3.86:4.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.86:4.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.86:4.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.86:4.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.86:4.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.86:4.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.86:4.6.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an3.86:4.6.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an3.86:5.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī paññāya paripūrakārī.
an3.86:5.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an3.86:5.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.86:5.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.86:5.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.86:5.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.86:5.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.86:5.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.86:5.6.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an3.86:5.6.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an3.86:6.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, padesaṃ padesakārī ārādheti paripūraṃ paripūrakārī.
an3.86:6.1.eng: So, mendicants, if you practice partially you succeed partially. If you practice fully you succeed fully.

an3.86:6.2.eng: But in any case, these training rules are not a waste, I say.”

an3.87:1.1.pli: “Sādhikamidaṃ, bhikkhave, diyaḍḍhasikkhāpadasataṃ anvaddhamāsaṃ uddesaṃ āgacchati yattha attakāmā kulaputtā sikkhanti.
an3.87:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, each fortnight over a hundred and fifty training rules come up for recitation, in which gentlemen who desire self-knowledge train.

an3.87:1.2.pli: Tisso imā, bhikkhave, sikkhā yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchati.
an3.87:1.2.eng: These are all included in the three trainings.

an3.87:1.4.eng: The training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.

an3.87:1.5.pli: imā kho, bhikkhave, tisso sikkhā yatthetaṃ sabbaṃ samodhānaṃ gacchati.
an3.87:1.5.eng: These are the three trainings that include them all.

an3.87:2.1.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ mattaso kārī paññāya mattaso kārī.
an3.87:2.1.eng: Take the case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics, but has limited immersion and wisdom.

an3.87:2.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.87:2.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.87:2.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.87:2.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.87:2.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.87:2.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual life. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.87:2.6.pli: So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sattakkhattuparamo hoti.
an3.87:2.6.eng: With the ending of three fetters they have at most seven rebirths.

an3.87:2.7.pli: Sattakkhattuparamaṃ deve ca manusse ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.87:2.7.eng: They will transmigrate at most seven times among gods and humans and then make an end of suffering.

an3.87:2.8.pli: So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā kolaṅkolo hoti, dve vā tīṇi vā kulāni sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.87:2.8.eng: With the ending of three fetters, they go from family to family. They will transmigrate between two or three families and then make an end of suffering.

an3.87:2.9.pli: So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā ekabījī hoti, ekaṃyeva mānusakaṃ bhavaṃ nibbattetvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.87:2.9.eng: With the ending of three fetters, they’re a one-seeder. They will be reborn just one time in a human existence, then make an end of suffering.

an3.87:2.10.pli: So tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an3.87:2.10.eng: With the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, they’re a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

an3.87:3.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī paññāya mattaso kārī.
an3.87:3.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics and immersion, but has limited wisdom.

an3.87:3.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.87:3.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.87:3.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.87:3.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.87:3.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.87:3.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.87:3.6.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī.
an3.87:3.6.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they head upstream, going to the Akaniṭṭha realm.

an3.87:3.7.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.87:3.7.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished with extra effort.

an3.87:3.8.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.87:3.8.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished without extra effort.

an3.87:3.9.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā upahaccaparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.87:3.9.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished upon landing.

an3.87:3.10.pli: So pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā antarāparinibbāyī hoti.
an3.87:3.10.eng: With the ending of the five lower fetters they’re extinguished between one life and the next.

an3.87:4.1.pli: Idha pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlesu paripūrakārī hoti samādhismiṃ paripūrakārī paññāya paripūrakārī.
an3.87:4.1.eng: Take another case of a mendicant who has fulfilled their ethics, immersion, and wisdom.

an3.87:4.2.pli: So yāni tāni khuddānukhuddakāni sikkhāpadāni tāni āpajjatipi vuṭṭhātipi.
an3.87:4.2.eng: They break some lesser and minor training rules, but are restored.

an3.87:4.4.pli: Na hi mettha, bhikkhave, abhabbatā vuttā.
an3.87:4.4.eng: Because I don’t say they’re incapable of that.

an3.87:4.5.pli: Yāni ca kho tāni sikkhāpadāni ādibrahmacariyakāni brahmacariyasāruppāni, tattha dhuvasīlo ca hoti ṭhitasīlo ca, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu.
an3.87:4.5.eng: But they’re constant and steady in their precepts regarding the training rules that are fundamental, befitting the spiritual path. They keep the rules they’ve undertaken.

an3.87:4.6.pli: So āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an3.87:4.6.eng: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an3.87:5.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, padesaṃ padesakārī ārādheti, paripūraṃ paripūrakārī, avañjhāni tvevāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sikkhāpadāni vadāmī”ti.
an3.87:5.1.eng: So, mendicants, if you practice partially you succeed partially. If you practice fully you succeed fully. But in any case, these training rules are not a waste, I say.”
